customer_addr:
VETERINARY MEDICAL TECHNOLOGY
1015 PHILADELPHIA AVE
CHAMBERSBURG, PA 17201

citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care.
citations.narrative:
During the inspection, a bottle of meloxicam (Metacam) with an expiration date of 04/2024 was found in an animal room.
The facility representative confirmed that the medication was currently being used to treat a gerbil, "Eugenie."
The use of expired medications is not considered to be an appropriate method to treat diseases or injuries since the effect
of the drug may be variable. Animals may experience unintended discomfort if the expired medication does not provide
the anticipated effect.
As part of an adequate veterinary care program, the facility must use appropriate methods to prevent, control, diagnose,
and treat diseases and injuries which include procedures to ensure that expired medications are not administered to
animals.
The facility representative discarded the medication during the inspection on October 17, 2024.

In February 2024, the facility tested their dogs for parasites and did not properly document the treatments performed. At
that time, three of the dogs had positive fecal results and received medication, however, the plan for treatment and
treatment procedures were not documented in the medical records.
It's important to maintain complete and accurate medical records to ensure that the dogs are provided appropriate
treatments when problems are identified.
Medical records for dogs must include any identified problems, the date and description of the problem, examination
findings, test results, a plan for treatment, and treatment procedures performed when appropriate.
Correct by: October 28, 2024.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
n

narrative:
2.33(b)(2) 
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care. 
During the inspection, a bottle of meloxicam (Metacam) with an expiration date of 04/2024 was found in an animal room. 
The facility representative confirmed that the medication was currently being used to treat a gerbil, "Eugenie."  
The use of expired medications is not considered to be an appropriate method to treat diseases or injuries since the effect 
of the drug may be variable. Animals may experience unintended discomfort if the expired medication does not provide 
the anticipated effect.  
As part of an adequate veterinary care program, the facility must use appropriate methods to prevent, control, diagnose, 
and treat diseases and injuries which include procedures to ensure that expired medications are not administered to 
animals.  
The facility representative discarded the medication during the inspection on October 17, 2024. 
3.13(b)(2) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
In February 2024, the facility tested their dogs for parasites and did not properly document the treatments performed. At 
that time, three of the dogs had positive fecal results and received medication, however, the plan for treatment and 
treatment procedures were not documented in the medical records.  
It's important to maintain complete and accurate medical records to ensure that the dogs are provided appropriate 
treatments when problems are identified.  
Medical records for dogs must include any identified problems, the date and description of the problem, examination 
findings, test results, a plan for treatment, and treatment procedures performed when appropriate.  
Correct by: October 28, 2024. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
